text: Is $(x, y) = (3, 0)$ a solution of the system $\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 6 \\ 4x - y = 1 \end{cases}$?
solution: $(x, y) = (3, 0)$ is a solution for the first equation, as $6 + 0 = 6$, however, it is not a solution of the second equation as $12 - 0 \neq 1$.

text: Which of the following is a solution to the linear system $\begin{cases} -2x + y = 3 \\ 3x - y = 1 \end{cases}$ in the variables $(x,y)$?
solution: By setting $x = 4$ and $y = 11$, we get $-8 + 11 = 3$ and $12 - 11 = 1$, thus $(x, y) = (4, 11)$ is a solution of the system. Setting $x = 5$ and $y = -1$ results in $15 + 1 = 16$, which is not valid. Similarly, $(x, y) = (0, 3)$ fails to satisfy the system.

text: For a linear system of the form $\begin{cases} 7x + y = 1 \\ x - 2y = 0 \end{cases}$, what is correct?
solution: There are at least the two variables $x$ and $y$. However, there could be more variables (for example, a variable $z$) that do not appear in the equations.

text: What is correct for a linear system?
answerOptions: A reordering of the equations does not change the solution set.
A reordering of the variables does not change the solution set.
correctAnswer: A reordering of the equations does not change the solution set.
solution: The solution set is the intersection of the solution sets of the individual equations. Reordering the equations does not affect the solution set. However, reordering the variables can change the solutions since it would alter the relationships between the variables.

text: If two equations in a linear system are the same, one of them can be deleted.
solution: The solution set of the system remains unchanged by removing the repeated equation, as intersecting the solution set with itself multiple times does not alter the solution.

text: The solution set of a system of linear equations is the union of the solution sets of the individual equations.
solution: The solution set of a system of linear equations is the intersection of the solution sets of the individual equations, not their union.

text: Select the correct matrix, representing the linear system $\begin{cases} 2y + z - 1 = -x \\ 2z = 3 - 5z \\ 3x + z = 0 \end{cases}$
solution: The constant terms in the augmented matrix must have the signs as they are on the right side of the equations.

text: What does an equation in a linear system correspond to?
answerOptions: A row of the augmented matrix of the linear system
A column of the augmented matrix of the linear system
correctAnswer: A row of the augmented matrix of the linear system
solution: By definition, a row of the augmented matrix contains the coefficients of the variables and the constant term for one equation of the system.

text: Does each column of the augmented matrix correspond to a variable of the linear system?
solution: Each column of the augmented matrix represents the coefficients of the same variable across the equations, except for the last column, which holds the constant terms.

text: Consider the equation $x + y + 1 = 0$ in the real variables $x, y, z$. What is correct?
solution: The equation is linear because, written in the form $x + y = -1$, it states that a sum of multiples of the variables is a constant. It is not homogeneous because there is a non-zero constant term. It is consistent (and hence not inconsistent) because $(x, y, z) = (-1, 0, 0)$ is a solution.

text: Which properties does the linear system $\begin{cases} 3x + y = 0 \\ 2x + 1 - 3y = 1 \end{cases}$ have?
solution: The system is consistent and homogeneous because the trivial solution $(x, y) = (0, 0)$ exists. The second equation can be rewritten as $2x - 3y = 0$, showing homogeneity.

text: Which properties does the linear system $\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 5 \\ 4x - y = 1 \end{cases}$ have?
solution: The system is consistent because there is a solution $(x, y) = \left(\frac{4}{7}, \frac{9}{7}\right)$. It is not homogeneous because $(x, y) = (0, 0)$ is not a solution.

text: Consider a linear system (over $\mathbb{R}$) with $n$ variables. Which properties are equivalent to the system being homogeneous?
answerOptions: The system has the same number of equations and variables
The system has at least one solution
The constant term of each equation is zero
The $n$-tuple $(0, \ldots, 0)$ is a solution to the system
The $n$-tuple $(0, \ldots, 0)$ is a solution to at least one equation
The right-hand side of each equation is zero
Each equation of the system is homogeneous
correctAnswer: The constant term of each equation is zero
The $n$-tuple $(0, \ldots, 0)$ is a solution to the system
solution: The system is homogeneous if and only if the constant term of each equation is zero or, equivalently, if the $n$-tuple $(0, \ldots, 0)$ is a solution to the system. Having the same number of equations and variables, having at least one solution, or the $n$-tuple $(0, \ldots, 0)$ being a solution to at least one equation are not sufficient to imply homogeneity.

text: Which of the following linear systems (over $\mathbb{R}$) have at least one solution?
answerOptions: All linear systems with the same number of equations and variables
All linear systems such that each equation has a solution
solution: All consistent linear systems have a solution by definition. All homogeneous linear systems have the trivial solution $(0, \ldots, 0)$, so there is at least one solution.

text: What is correct for a linear system?
answerOptions: If all variables are leading variables, there is at most one solution
If all variables are free variables, there is at least one solution
correctAnswer: If all variables are leading variables, there is at most one solution
solution: If all variables are leading variables, then there is no free variable. So the solution set, if non-empty, will contain no parameter and the solution is unique. If all variables are free variables, there could be no solutions (e.g., $0x=1$).

text: We express the leading variables as a sum of the free variables and possibly a constant term.
solution: We express a leading variable as a sum of multiples of the free variables and possibly a constant term.

text: For a linear system, if there are more variables than equations, there must be free variables.
solution: By inspecting the augmented matrix, the number of leading variables is at most the number of equations. If the latter exceeds the total number of variables, then there must be free variables.

text: If there are more equations than variables, the system has no solutions.
solution: Starting with a linear equation that has solutions, repeating it an arbitrary amount of times will lead to a consistent linear system with an arbitrary amount of equations.

text: For a linear system, the number of leading variables is at most the number of distinct variables that appear in the system's equations.
solution: A leading variable is in particular a variable of the linear system. The variables are partitioned into leading variables and free variables. A system's variable not appearing in the equations is a free variable.

text: The number of free variables is at most the number of leading variables.
solution: A counterexample is the equation $x=3$ in the variables $(x,y,z)$, where the leading variable is $x$ and the free variables are $y$ and $z$. The number of free variables and leading variables are non-negative integers that add up to the total number of variables.

text: For a linear system, the number of free variables is the number of variables minus the number of leading variables.
solution: The variables are partitioned into leading variables and free variables. So the sum of the number of leading variables and the number of free variables gives the number of variables.

text: For a linear system, the number of leading variables equals the number of non-zero rows of the augmented matrix of the system.
solution: The number of leading variables equals the number of non-zero rows of the augmented matrix when this is transformed into row echelon form. The row echelon form of a matrix may have more zero rows than the original matrix.

text: Consider the augmented matrix of a linear system in row echelon form, and remove the last column. The number of non-zero rows equals the number of leading variables.
solution: We call leading variable a variable whose corresponding column has a leading entry. There is at most one leading entry in each column, so the number of leading variables is the number of leading entries. Each non-zero row contains exactly one leading entry.

text: Which of the following operations can be performed to the augmented matrix of a linear system while solving the system (over $\mathbb{R}$)?
answerOptions: Multiplying a row by a scalar
Add a row to a different row
Add to a row a multiple of a different row
Add to a row a multiple of itself
correctAnswer: Add a row to a different row
Add to a row a multiple of a different row
solution: We may swap rows, and by performing multiple swaps, we can permute the rows in any way. We may add the multiple of a row to a different row but not to itself (adding the negative of a row to itself would mean replacing the row by the zero row). Adding a row to itself is the same as multiplying the row by $2$.

text: The order of the elementary row operations matters.
solution: Swapping the first two rows and multiplying the first row by $5$ do not commute, as can be seen on the $2\times 2$ identity matrix.

text: Performing elementary row operations does not change the common solutions of the corresponding equations.
solution: Swapping two equations does not change the set of common solutions (the intersection of sets is commutative). Multiplying an equation by a non-zero scalar results in an equivalent equation with the same solutions. Adding to a given equation the multiple of another equation also does not alter the common solutions.

text: Can the second matrix be obtained from the first by performing elementary row operations? \(\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 7 & 2 &\bigm| & 1 \\ 8 & 1 & 2 &\bigm| & 3 \\ 3 & 3 & 6 &\bigm| & 0 \end{pmatrix}\) and \(\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 4 & -4 &\bigm| & 1 \\ 9 & 5 & -2 &\bigm| & 4 \\ 3 & 3 & 6 &\bigm| & 0 \end{pmatrix}\)
solution: The second matrix can be obtained from the former matrix by subtracting the third row from the first row. Adding the the first row to the second row gives the latter matrix.

text: Can we perform elementary column operations to the augmented matrix of a linear system while solving the system?
solution: Column operations change the solution set. For example, adding the first column to the second would turn $x+y=1$ into $x+2y=1$.

text: For a matrix in row echelon form, which of the following properties hold? (Note: the leading entry is the left-most nonzero entry)
answerOptions: The matrix is necessary a square matrix
The leading entry of each non-zero row is to the right of the leading entry of the previous row
All entries below a leading entry are zero
correctAnswer: The leading entry of each non-zero row is to the right of the leading entry of the previous row
All entries below a leading entry are zero
solution: For the row echelon form, the number of rows and columns does not matter, and in particular the matrix does not need to be a square matrix. The second and third statements are correct because the leading entries follow a "ladder" pattern in the row echelon form.

text: What is correct for a matrix (with entries in $\mathbb{R}$)?
answerOptions: There is a unique row echelon form.
There may not be a reduced row echelon form.
There is a unique reduced row echelon form.
correctAnswer: There is a unique reduced row echelon form.
solution: Every matrix has precisely one reduced row echelon form. However, there are infinitely many row echelon forms (for example, multiplying a non-zero row by any non-zero scalar gives infinitely many distinct row echelon forms).

text: For a matrix, what is correct?
answerOptions: Being in reduced row echelon form is necessary for being in row echelon form.
Being in reduced row echelon form is sufficient for being in row echelon form.
correctAnswer: Being in reduced row echelon form is sufficient for being in row echelon form.
solution: The condition of being in reduced row echelon form is more restrictive than the one of being in row echelon form. The stronger condition is sufficient for the weaker condition but not necessary.

text: If an elementary row operation is applied to a matrix that is in row echelon form, the resulting matrix is in row echelon form.
solution: As a counterexample, consider the $2\times 2$ identity matrix: it is in reduced row echelon form, but swapping the two rows will lead to a matrix that is not in row echelon form.

text: For a linear system, if the reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix has a row of zeros, then the system has infinitely many solutions.
solution: A counterexample is the system $\begin{cases} x = 2 \\ 0x = 0 \end{cases}$ with the variable $x$. Indeed, the second row of the augmented matrix is zero, but there is a unique solution $x=2$.

text: What is correct for a matrix?
answerOptions: In row echelon form, the first non-zero entry in a non-zero row is 1.
In reduced row echelon form, the first entry in a non-zero row is 1.
solution: In row echelon form, the first non-zero entry is not necessarily 1. In reduced row echelon form, the first non-zero entry must be 1, but the first entry could still be 0.

text: Consider the augmented matrix of a linear system. If the row echelon form has a leading 1 in the last column, the system is not solvable.
solution: A row with leading 1 in the last column corresponds to an equation that has no solutions, such as $0x_1+\ldots+0x_n=1$.

text: Is the linear system (over $\mathbb{R}$) with augmented matrix $\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -1 &\bigm| 4 \\ 0 & 0 &\bigm| 2 \end{pmatrix}$ consistent?
solution: The second row represents the equation $0x+0y=2$, which has no solutions (any value for the variables leads to the false identity $0=2$).

text: What is true about the number of elementary row operations needed to transform a matrix into row echelon form?
answerOptions: It depends on the number of columns
It depends on the number of rows
It depends on the number of entries
correctAnswer: It depends on the number of rows
It depends on the number of columns
solution: The number of elementary row operations required is bounded by a function of the number of rows and columns of the matrix.

text: Consider the linear system $\begin{cases} x-2y=1 \\ z=5 \end{cases}$ in the variables $(x,y,z)$. Knowing that there is precisely one free variable, what is the solution set of the system?
solution: The second set is the correct solution. Setting $t=0$ gives a solution $(2,1,5)$ and it matches the system. There cannot be further solutions as there is only one free variable.

text: What is the solution set of the linear system $\begin{cases} 2x + y = a \\ 2x + y = b \end{cases}$, where $a$ and $b$ are distinct real numbers?
solution: Since $a \neq b$, the system has no solutions. A single value $2x + y$ cannot equal two distinct numbers.

text: Which of the following statements are correct for a linear system?
answerOptions: In the solution set, we express the leading variables in terms of the free variables.
In the solution set, we express the free variables in terms of the leading variables.
correctAnswer: In the solution set, we express the leading variables in terms of the free variables.
solution: Free variables can take any value, while leading variables depend on them. This is why we express the leading variables in terms of the free variables.

text: Which of the following linear systems (over $\mathbb{R}$) have infinitely many solutions?
answerOptions: All consistent not homogeneous linear systems
All linear systems having at least two distinct solutions
All linear systems such that each equation has infinitely many solutions
correctAnswer: All linear systems having at least two distinct solutions
solution: If a system has at least two solutions, then the solution set must contain at least one free variable, leading to infinitely many solutions.

text: How many distinct solutions can a linear system (over $\mathbb{R}$) have?
answerOptions: In any case, not more than the number of equations in the system
solution: Linear systems can have either no solutions, a unique solution, or infinitely many solutions depending on the conditions of the system.

text: Consider the augmented matrix of a linear system. Removing a zero row or column does not affect the solution set.
solution: Removing a zero row is valid as it doesn't affect the system. However, removing a column eliminates a variable, which can change the solution set.

text: The linear system $\begin{cases} x - y = 3 \\ 2x - 2y = k \end{cases}$, where $k$ is a real number, cannot have a unique solution.
solution: The system is equivalent to $\begin{cases} 2x - 2y = 6 \\ 2x - 2y = k \end{cases}$. If $k \neq 6$, there are no solutions; if $k = 6$, there are infinitely many solutions.

text: If each equation of a linear system is multiplied by a nonzero constant, then the solutions of the new system can be obtained by multiplying the solutions from the original system by that constant.
solution: Multiplying the equations by a nonzero constant does not change the solution set. The system remains equivalent, and the solutions are not scaled by the constant.

text: Summing two solutions of a linear system gives a solution of the system.
solution: The sum of two solutions of an inhomogeneous linear system is generally not a solution of the system.

text: Summing two solutions of a homogeneous linear system gives a solution of the system.
solution: In a homogeneous system, the sum of two solutions is also a solution, since the system's equations are satisfied by the sum.

text: Summing a solution of an inhomogeneous linear system and a solution of the associated homogeneous linear system gives a solution of the:
solution: Summing a solution from an inhomogeneous system with one from the homogeneous counterpart still satisfies the original inhomogeneous system.

text: How many linear equations are needed to define a line in $\mathbb{R}^3$?
solution: In $\mathbb{R}^3$, a linear equation has as solution set a plane through the origin, unless all coefficients of the variables are zero (in which case there are no solutions or the solution set is $\mathbb{R}^3$). So we need at least two equations to determine a line (the intersection of two distinct planes through the origin is a line through the origin).

text: Suppose that a linear system has infinitely many solutions. What can be said about the solution set of the system and the solution set of the associated homogeneous linear system (seen as geometrical objects)?
solution: The solution set of the corresponding homogeneous system is a translate (more precisely, the translate through the origin) of the solution set of the system. So they are parallel. They are identical only when the original system is already homogeneous.

text: In $\mathbb{R}^2$, the equation $ax + by = c$ (where $a,b,c$ are real numbers) represents a line.
solution: The equation $0x + 0y = c$ has as solution set the empty set (if $c\neq 0$) or $\mathbb{R}^2$ (if $c=0$).

text: In $\mathbb{R}^2$, the solution set to a linear system can be:
solution: The solution set can be the empty set ($0x+0y=1$), the whole plane ($0x+0y=0$), any line $(x,y)=(t,at+b)$ or any point $(x,y)=(a,b)$, when the system has a single solution. So, the solution set cannot be the unit circle, a half-plane, a line not through the origin, or a point that is not the origin.

text: In $\mathbb{R}^2$, the solution set to a homogenious linear system can be:
solution: The solution set can be only be the whole plane ($0x+0y=0$) or a point in the origin. Else, the solution set must be the origin $(x,y)=(0,0)$ or a line through the origin. So, the solution set cannot be the unit circle, a half-plane, a line not through the origin, or a point that is not the origin.

text: The two lines represented by the equations $2x + 4y = 3$ and $x + 2y = 1$ are:
solution: We can rewrite the second equation as $2x + 4y = 2$. As the two equations differ by the constant term, there is no common solution. As each equation represents a line, we have two lines that do not intersect, so they are parallel but not identical.

text:
Solve the system of equations:
$\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 6 \\ 4x - y = 5 \end{cases}$

Solve the system of equations:
$\begin{cases} x + 2y + z = 4 \\ 5x - y + 3z = 3 \\ 3x + 5y - z = 6 \end{cases}$

Solve the system of equations:
$\begin{cases} 3x + 4y = 10 \\ 5x - 7y = 3 \end{cases}$

Solve the system of equations:
$\begin{cases} x - y + z = 2 \\ 2x + y - 3z = -1 \\ -x + 4y + 2z = 7 \end{cases}$

Solve the system of equations:
$\begin{cases} 2x + y - z = 3 \\ x - 2y + 3z = -1 \\ 3x + y + 2z = 4 \end{cases}$

Perform Gauss-Jordan elimination on the matrix:
$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & -1 & \bigm| 3 \\ 2 & 1 & -2 & \bigm| 1 \\ -3 & 1 & 1 & \bigm| -2 \end{pmatrix}$

Perform simple Gauss elimination on the matrix:
$\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -1 & 3 & \bigm| 4 \\ 1 & 3 & -2 & \bigm| 1 \\ 3 & 2 & -1 & \bigm| 5 \end{pmatrix}$
answerOptions: There can be multiple matrices and none of the above is correct
correctAnswer: There can be multiple matrices and none of the above is correct

text: The size of a matrix is written as $x \times y$, where...
answerOptions: $x$ is the number of rows, $y$ is a number of columns
$x$ is the number of columns, $y$ is a number of rows
correctAnswer: $x$ is the number of rows, $y$ is a number of columns
solution: A matrix size is determined as $x \times y$, where $x$ is the number of rows, $y$ is a number of columns.

text: What is the size of the following matrix? $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 7 & -4 \\ 6 & -2 & -2 \\ 3 & 3 & 6 \\ 1 & 2 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$
solution: A matrix size is determined as $x \times y$, where $x$ is the number of rows, $y$ is a number of columns.

text: In which entry of the matrix $M$ is the value equal to 0? $\begin{pmatrix} 3 & 7 & -2 \\ 0 & -2 & -3 \\ 5 & 3 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$
solution: The entry that occurs in row $i$ and column $j$ (starting from 1) of a matrix $M$ is usually denoted by $(M)_{ij}$ or by $m_{ij}$, so the entry in the second row and the first column is denoted as $(M)_{21}$.

text: What is the order of the following matrix? $\begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 & -2 \\ 1 & 0 & 9 \\ 2 & 3 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$
answerOptions: It does not have an order
solution: A matrix of size $n \times n$ is a square matrix of order $n$, so in this case of order 3.

text: What is the order of the following matrix? $\begin{pmatrix} 3 & 0 & -1 \\ 2 & -8 & -2 \end{pmatrix}$
answerOptions: It does not have an order
correctAnswer: It does not have an order
solution: Only square matrices have an order.

text: Select correct statements about the following matrix. $\begin{pmatrix} 8 & 0 & -1 & 3 \\ 2 & -8 & -2 & 4 \\ 2 & 1 & -2 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$
solution: This matrix is $3 \times 4$, as it has 3 rows and 4 columns, so it is not square and therefore does not have an order. The total number of entries in the matrix is equal to $\#_{rows} \times \#_{cols}$, $3 \times 4 = 12$.

text: The main diagonal of $n \times n$ matrix $A$ are entries $a_{11}, a_{22}, \ldots, a_{nn}$?
solution: This can be easily shown on a matrix $\begin{pmatrix} a_{11} & a_{12} \\ a_{21} & a_{22} \end{pmatrix}$ where $a_{11}$ and $a_{22}$ form the main diagonal.

text: What is the trace of the matrix? $\begin{pmatrix} -2 & 0 & 9 \\ 1 & 4 & -3 \\ 0 & 0 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$
solution: The entries on the main diagonal are $-2, 4, 2$ and their sum is 4.

text: Any two matrices can be added or subtracted.
solution: We can only add two matrices if they have the same size.

text: If $A$ and $B$ are matrices of the same size, then $A+B = B+A$.
solution: Matrix addition is commutative, meaning $A+B = B+A$.

text: Perform a matrix addition of matrices $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 4 \\ 3 & -4 & -3 \\ 8 & 1 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 5 & -6 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 & 2 \\ 6 & 0 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$.
solution: The result of summing two matrices is a new matrix, each entry of which is the sum of the corresponding entries of the matrices that have been added ($((C)_{ij} = (A)_{ij} + (B)_{ij})$).

text: Multiply the following matrix by the scalar 3: $\begin{pmatrix} 0 & -2 \\ 1 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$.
solution: Each entry of the matrix is multiplied by the scalar of 3.

text: Perform the matrix subtraction of the following matrices: $\begin{pmatrix} 7 & 5 \\ 3 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 1 \\ 2 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$.
solution: Each entry of the resulting matrix is the difference of the corresponding entries of the matrices.

text: What is a linear combination of matrices?
answerOptions: A linear combination of matrices is the sum of scalar multiples of those matrices.
A linear combination of matrices is the product of the matrices.
A linear combination of matrices involves adding matrices after multiplying each by a scalar.
A linear combination of matrices is the subtraction of one matrix from another.
correctAnswer: A linear combination of matrices is the sum of scalar multiples of those matrices.
A linear combination of matrices involves adding matrices after multiplying each by a scalar.
solution: A linear combination of matrices is the sum of scalar multiples of those matrices (e.g. for matrices $A, \ B, \ C$, and scalars $x, \ y, \ z$, $xA + yB - zC$ will be one of the possible linear combinations).

text: For two matrices $A$ and $B$, the product $AB$ is defined if and only if the number of columns in $A$ is equal to the number of rows in $B$.
solution: Matrix multiplication is defined only when the number of columns in the first matrix is equal to the number of rows in the second matrix.

text: If $A$ is an $n \times m$ matrix and $B$ is an $m \times k$ matrix, what will be the dimensions of the resulting matrix $AB$?
solution: The resulting matrix $AB$ will have the number of rows of $A$ and the number of columns of $B$, which is $n \times k$.

text: The product of two matrices $A$ and $B$ is always commutative, i.e., $AB = BA$ (assuming that $AB$ is defined).
solution: Matrix multiplication is generally not commutative, as we can only multiply matrices with the sizes $n \times m$ and $m \times k$, resulting in a $n \times k$ matrix. Swapping the matrices places results in the multiplication of $m \times k$ and $n \times m$ matrices, which is impossible if $n \neq k$, meaning that in most cases the operation is impossible.

text: Which of the following statements about matrix multiplication is true?
answerOptions: The product of two matrices is always a square matrix.
The product of two matrices is always a matrix of the same size as the original matrices.
The product of two matrices $A$ and $B$ is a matrix where each entry is the sum of the products of the corresponding entries from the rows of $A$ and the columns of $B$.
The product of two matrices is always a diagonal matrix.
correctAnswer: The product of two matrices $A$ and $B$ is a matrix where each entry is the sum of the products of the corresponding entries from the rows of $A$ and the columns of $B$.
solution: This statement correctly describes how each entry in the resulting matrix is computed during matrix multiplication.

text: Which of the following properties does matrix multiplication satisfy?
solution: Matrix multiplication is associative, meaning $(AB)C = A(BC)$, and distributive, meaning $A(B + C) = AB + AC$. However, it is not commutative.

text: Calculate the product of the following matrices: $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ 1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$.
solution: Each entry of the resulting matrix is calculated by taking the dot product of the corresponding row of the first matrix and the column of the second.

text: Calculate the product of the following matrices: $\begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 \\ 6 & 7 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$.
solution: The sizes of the matrices are $3 \times 2$ and $2 \times 3$, so the result is a $3 \times 3$ matrix. Each entry of the resulting matrix is calculated by taking the dot product of the corresponding row of the first matrix and the column of the second.

text: The transpose of a matrix $A$, denoted as $A^T$, is obtained by swapping its rows and columns.
solution: The transpose of a matrix is formed by interchanging its rows and columns.

text: Which of the following statements about the transpose of a matrix is true?
answerOptions: The transpose of a matrix is always a square matrix.
The transpose of a matrix $A$ is obtained by multiplying each entry of $A$ by -1.
The transpose of a matrix $A$ is obtained by swapping its rows and columns.
The transpose of a matrix $A$ is obtained by adding a scalar to each entry of $A$.
correctAnswer: The transpose of a matrix $A$ is obtained by swapping its rows and columns.
solution: This statement correctly describes how the transpose of a matrix is formed.

text: Which of the following properties does the transpose operation satisfy?
solution: The transpose of the transpose of a matrix is the original matrix, the transpose of a sum of matrices is the sum of their transposes, and the transpose of a product of matrices is the product of their transposes in reverse order.

text: Find the transpose of the following matrix: $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 & 6 \end{pmatrix}$.
solution: The transpose of matrix $A$ is obtained by swapping its rows and columns.

text: Find the transpose of the following matrix: $\begin{pmatrix} 7 & 8 \\ 9 & 10 \\ 11 & 12 \end{pmatrix}$.
solution: The transpose of a matrix is obtained by swapping its rows and columns.

text: If $M$ is a $3 \times 2$ matrix, what will be the dimensions of $M^T$?
solution: The transpose of a $m \times n$ matrix is a $n \times m$ matrix.

text: What is a zero matrix?
answerOptions: A matrix with all entries equal to zero.
A matrix with all entries equal to one.
A matrix with all entries equal to the same non-zero value.
correctAnswer: A matrix with all entries equal to zero.
solution: A zero matrix is a matrix in which all the entries are zero.

text: Which of the following is a property of a zero matrix?
answerOptions: It is the additive identity in matrix addition.
It is always a square matrix.
correctAnswer: It is the additive identity in matrix addition.
solution: The zero matrix is the additive identity because adding it to any matrix $A$ results in $A$.

text: What is a triangular matrix?
answerOptions: A matrix with all entries equal to zero.
A matrix that is either upper triangular or lower triangular.
A matrix with all entries equal to one.
A matrix with non-zero entries only on the diagonal.
correctAnswer: A matrix that is either upper triangular or lower triangular.
solution: A triangular matrix is one that is either upper triangular (all entries below the main diagonal are zero) or lower triangular (all entries above the main diagonal are zero).

text: Which of the following is true for an upper triangular matrix?
answerOptions: All entries below the main diagonal are zero.
All entries above the main diagonal are zero.
All entries on the main diagonal are zero.
correctAnswer: All entries below the main diagonal are zero.

text: Which of the following is true for a lower triangular matrix?
answerOptions: All entries below the main diagonal are zero.

text: What is an identity matrix?

A matrix with non-zero entries only on the main diagonal.
correctAnswer: A matrix with ones on the main diagonal and zeros elsewhere.

text: Which of the following is a property of the identity matrix?
answerOptions: It is the multiplicative identity in matrix multiplication.
solution: The identity matrix is the multiplicative identity, is always invertible, and is its own inverse.

text: What is a symmetrical matrix?
answerOptions: A matrix that is equal to its transpose.
A matrix with all entries equal to zero.
A matrix with all entries equal to one.
A matrix with non-zero entries only on the diagonal.
correctAnswer: A matrix that is equal to its transpose.
solution: A symmetrical matrix is one that is equal to its transpose, meaning $A = A^T$.

text: Which of the following is a property of a symmetrical matrix?
answerOptions: It is always a square matrix.
If a linear system has a symmetrical coefficient matrix, it is always consistent.
correctAnswer: It is always a square matrix.
solution: The only correct statement is that symmetric matrices are always square matrices, as in order for the matrix to be equal to its own transpose, it must keep its dimensions unchanged. The other statements are incorrect.

text: Which of the following matrices is symmetrical?
solution: $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$, $\begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 1 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$ are symmetrical because they are equal to their transposes.

text: What is a skew-symmetric matrix?
answerOptions: A matrix that is equal to its transpose.
A matrix that is equal to the negative of its transpose.
A matrix with all entries equal to zero.
A matrix with non-zero entries only on the diagonal.
correctAnswer: A matrix that is equal to the negative of its transpose.
solution: A skew-symmetric matrix is one that satisfies $A = -A^T$.

text: Which of the following is a property of a skew-symmetric matrix?
answerOptions: It is always a square matrix.
The trace of skew-symmetric matrix is equal to 0.
correctAnswer: It is always a square matrix.
The trace of skew-symmetric matrix is equal to 0.
solution: Skew-symmetric matrices are always square matrices, and all diagonal entries are zero, resulting in a trace of 0. However, not all skew-symmetric matrices are invertible.

text: Which of the following matrices is skew-symmetric?
solution: $\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 2 \\ -2 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$, $\begin{pmatrix} 0 & -1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$, and $\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$ are skew-symmetric because they are equal to the negative of their transposes.

text: What conditions must a square matrix satisfy to be considered invertible?
answerOptions: It must be a square matrix.
It must have rank equal to the number of rows (or columns).
solution: A matrix is invertible if it is square, has a non-zero determinant, and has rank equal to the number of rows (or columns).

answerOptions: The identity matrix is always invertible.

text: How does the concept of row echelon form help in determining the invertibility of a square matrix?
answerOptions: A matrix in row echelon form is always invertible.
A matrix is invertible if its row echelon form has no zero rows.
A matrix is invertible if its row echelon form has at least one zero row.
correctAnswer: A matrix is invertible if its row echelon form has no zero rows.
solution: If a matrix can be row reduced to row echelon form without any zero rows, it is invertible, as the matrix can be further simplified to the identity matrix using elementary row operations.

text: Describe the process of finding the inverse of a $2 \times 2$ matrix.
answerOptions: Swap the entries on the main diagonal, change the signs of the off-diagonal entries, and divide by the determinant.
Swap the entries on the main diagonal and multiply by the determinant.
Change the signs of all entries and divide by the determinant.
correctAnswer: Swap the entries on the main diagonal, change the signs of the off-diagonal entries, and divide by the determinant.
solution: For a $2 \times 2$ matrix $\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix}$, the inverse is $\frac{1}{ad - bc} \begin{pmatrix} d & -b \\ -c & a \end{pmatrix}$.

text: Can a non-square matrix be invertible? Why or why not?
answerOptions: Yes, because any matrix can have an inverse.
No, because only square matrices can have inverses.
Yes, if it has rank equal to the number of rows (or columns).
No, because non-square matrices do not have determinants.
correctAnswer: No, because only square matrices can have inverses.
No, because non-square matrices do not have determinants.
solution: Only square matrices can have inverses because the concept of an inverse requires the matrix to be able to multiply with another matrix to produce the identity matrix, which is only defined for square matrices. Also, for a matrix, having a non-zero determinant is an equivalent condition to being invertible, so both presented reasons why a non-square matrix can't be invertible are valid.
